message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings of retinal hemorrhages suggest the need for a noncontrast CT scan of the head to rule out any intracranial bleeding or trauma. The other options would not provide any information related to the cause of the infant’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The retinal hemorrhages are suggestive of non-accidental trauma or shaken baby syndrome. Noncontrast computed tomography of the head is most likely to be helpful in the management of the infant by detecting any head injury or bleeding that could be the cause of the symptoms. Hemoglobin electrophoresis, peripheral blood smear, and bone marrow aspiration are not likely to be helpful in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings in the infant suggest a possible shaken baby syndrome. A noncontrast computed tomography of the head can help determine if there is any intracranial bleeding or brain injury. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and peripheral blood smear are not relevant to this condition, and bone marrow aspiration is not necessary for the diagnosis or management of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of lethargy, decreased oral intake, and retinal hemorrhages suggests child abuse or Shaken Baby Syndrome. Noncontrast computed tomography of the head is the most appropriate investigation for detecting any brain injuries. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and bone marrow aspiration are unlikely to be helpful in this case, and a peripheral blood smear is not indicated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the presence of retinal hemorrhages suggest a possible diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome. A noncontrast computed tomography of the head is most likely to help in identifying any intracranial bleeding or injury. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and bone marrow aspiration are not relevant to this case, and a peripheral blood smear is not likely to provide much additional information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest abusive head trauma, and thus noncontrast computed tomography of the head is the most appropriate investigation to evaluate for intracranial injuries. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and peripheral blood smear are not indicated in this case, and bone marrow aspiration is not useful in the management of abusive head trauma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including lethargy and multiple retinal hemorrhages, suggest that the most likely cause is shaken baby syndrome. Noncontrast computed tomography of the head is the most useful investigation to evaluate for brain injury in shaken baby syndrome. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and bone marrow aspiration are not relevant in this case. Peripheral blood smear may show anemia, but it is not the most useful investigation in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest non-accidental trauma (NAT), also known as child abuse. Multiple retinal hemorrhages are a common finding in NAT. Noncontrast computed tomography of the head can help assess the extent of brain injury and guide further management in suspected cases of NAT. Hemoglobin electrophoresis, peripheral blood smear, and bone marrow aspiration are unlikely to be helpful in the management of this infant as they do not aid in the diagnosis of NAT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of retinal hemorrhages in a young infant suggests non-accidental injury (NAI), or commonly referred to as child abuse. A noncontrast computed tomography (CT) scan of the head is necessary to evaluate for associated head trauma. Hemoglobin electrophoresis, peripheral blood smear, and bone marrow aspiration are not relevant in the management of NAI.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and retinal hemorrhages suggest the possibility of shaken baby syndrome or abusive head trauma. Noncontrast CT of the head can be helpful in identifying any intracranial hemorrhage or other traumatic injuries. Hemoglobin electrophoresis, peripheral blood smear, and bone marrow aspiration are not indicated in this scenario.
